title: GymEnv pickled incorrectly
body:
In the samplers, we use `copy.deepcopy()` to copy `env_update`. This works fine when the environment has default `max_episode_length`. However, when copying an environment with a customized `max_episode_length`, the spec is copied wrongly. For example:
```py
import copy
from garage.envs import GymEnv

def copy_env():
    env = GymEnv('InvertedDoublePendulum-v2', max_episode_length=100)
    env_cp = copy.deepcopy(env)
    print(env.spec.max_episode_length)
    print(env_cp.spec.max_episode_length)

copy_env()
```
This code will output
```sh
100
1000
```

title: MTSAC not learning
body:
@avnishn 
Hi! Thank you for developing and maintaining this great repo. It makes developing and benchmarking models so much easier.

I am trying to run the baseline MTSAC on metaworld mt10 and mt50. However, it seems that the model is not learning anything (the success rate and return for each task are not changing much). For mt10, the success rate remains 0 at 3.6e+06 env steps / iteration 90 (with an average return of 3.08112). I'm observing similar things for mt50. Have you run into similar problems and do you have any suggestions on how I can approach those problems?

I am using the `2020-06` release of garage (installed from pip), with the correct metaworld version (the one provided in `setup.py`. The example scripts I'm using are from the 2020-06 release branch of the repo. The only thing I changed in the code was in `python3.6/site-packages/garage/torch/algos/sac.py` line 202, where I changed the `is` in the assert to a `==`, due to an error at the runtime of `mtsac_metaworld_mt10.py`, which should not affect the algorithm's performance. I also tested the `sac_half_cheetah_batch.py`, which trains normally as the return goes to a few thousand after some iterations.

Thanks a lot for your help! Please let me know if there's anything unclear in my description, or if you need any other information about this problem.

title: mtsac_metaworld_mt50.py sets num_tasks=10
body:
at commit: edf2615

the `MTSAC` object is created with `num_tasks=10`, even though being run with MT-50
```
mtsac = MTSAC(policy=policy,
                  qf1=qf1,
                  qf2=qf2,
                  gradient_steps_per_itr=150,
                  max_episode_length=150,
                  eval_env=mt50_test_envs,
                  env_spec=mt50_train_envs.spec,
                  num_tasks=10,   <---------------------------------------- HERE
                  steps_per_epoch=epoch_cycles,
                  replay_buffer=replay_buffer,
                  min_buffer_size=7500,
                  target_update_tau=5e-3,
                  discount=0.99,
                  buffer_batch_size=6400)
```

If the `MTSAC` class is intended to be used with `MultiEnvWrapper`, it should explicitly check that `num_tasks` is set properly. Or even just get the value directly from the wrapper.

title: Makefile Missing Backslash
body:
In Makefile the _run-nvidia_ target is missing a backslash:
```
run-nvidia: build-nvidia
	xhost +local:docker
	docker run \
		-it \
		--rm \
		--runtime=nvidia \
		-v /tmp/.X11-unix:/tmp/.X11-unix \
		-v $(DATA_PATH)/$(CONTAINER_NAME):/home/$(user)/code/garage/data \
		-e DISPLAY=$(DISPLAY) \
		-e QT_X11_NO_MITSHM=1 \
		-e MJKEY="$$(cat $(MJKEY_PATH))" \
		--name $(CONTAINER_NAME)  <<-------------------------------------- HERE
		${RUN_ARGS} \
		rlworkgroup/garage-nvidia ${RUN_CMD}
```

+++ b/src/garage/torch/algos/mtsac.py
@@ -186,6 +186,7 @@ class MTSAC(SAC):
                 obtain_evaluation_samples(
                     self.policy,
                     self._eval_env,
+                    max_path_length=self.max_path_length,
                     num_trajs=self._num_evaluation_trajectories))
         eval_trajs = TrajectoryBatch.concatenate(*eval_trajs)
         last_return = log_multitask_performance(epoch, eval_trajs,
```

title: TF 2.3.0 incompatibility
body: TF 2.3.0 was released yesterday, and seems to be incompatible with TFP <0.11.0 and breaks imports (https://travis-ci.com/github/rlworkgroup/garage/jobs/365922927#L3061). We pin TFP to <=0.10.0 in the first place to resolve cloudpickle version mismatch (https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/issues/1758). Since TFP 0.11.0 still pins cloudpickle to 1.3.0 while gym needs 1.2.x, unpinning TFP won't work. So for now, TF needs to be pinned to <2.3.0

Hi,

(1)
I am trying to reduce the required samples per epoch to make the epoch going faster. It seems that garage has a default TotalEnvSteps (to let each worker finish 128 periods?). I thought I can change something in runner or worker but failed to find it.

(2)

Thanks,
st2yang

title: Remove __get_unsupported_env_list()
body:
Currently, Bullet environments `MinitaurExtendedEnv`, `MinitaurReactiveEnv`, `MinitaurBallGymEnv`, `MinitaurTrottingEnv`, `MinitaurStandGymEnv`, `MinitaurAlternatingLegsEnv`, `MinitaurFourLegStandEnv` can't be used in garage as there are various source code errors. Currently we detects them via `_get_unsupported_env_list()` and skip these environments. 

Ideally, user expect garage to work with all gym environments.

body:
Hi, 
I am new to this framework but really like the whole setup of it. Unfortunately I have spent already quite some time to try and set up the VPG algorithm with the Cartpole Example in torch. I copy paste this example https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/master/examples/torch/vpg_pendulum.py
on line 32 I change 
```
    env = GarageEnv(env_name='InvertedDoublePendulum-v2')

with

    env = GarageEnv(env_name="CartPole-v1")

I then get the following error, line 92 in step of file gym/envs/classic_control/cartpole.py
assert self.action_space.contains(action), "%r (%s) invalid"%(action, type(action))
AssertionError: array([-0.9646216,  0.7912429], dtype=float32) (<class 'numpy.ndarray'>) invalid

The exact same thing happens when I follow your documentation https://garage.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/implement_algo.html and copy past the last  code snippet with an implementation of VPG. I again replace the environment to use the CartPole-v1 environment and the exact same thing happens. 

Thanks for your help

title: Possible Bug in garage/envs/base.py, unexpected attribute is_image
body:
I am using version 2020.4rc1
I follow more or lesse this tutorial https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/master/examples/tf/vpg_cartpole.py

When I execute
```environment = GarageEnv(env_name="CartPole-v1")```  I get the following error:

TypeError: from_gym() got an unexpected keyword argument 'is_image'

I am not sure If I am doing something wrong or if this is an issue. When I track down the stacktrace 
i get to the file /garage/envs/base.py and on line 62 I replace 
```
self.observation_space = akro.from_gym(self.env.observation_space,
                                               is_image=is_image)
```

with
 ```
self.observation_space = akro.from_gym(self.env.observation_space)
```

title: tar --auto-compress flag doesn't work on MacOS
body:
I get a `tar option not found error` when running examples calling experiment.py on MacOS:
`python garage/examples/tf/trpo_cartpole.py`
`tar: Option --auto-compress is not supported`

Found that linux has `tar` as `gnu tar`, whereas MacOS has `tar` as `bsdtar`, which by default doesn't support `--auto-compress`. 

Suggested fixes [here](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/master/src/garage/experiment/experiment.py#L728):
1: Add MacOS `gtar` dependency to install `gnu tar` for Mac users, and change `tar` to `gtar` if os is MacOS in code.
2: Remove `--auto-compress` if os is MacOS. Caveat: this can result in files compressed in different ways across linux and MacOS.

title: Policy.clone should also copy parameters
body:
This is not possible at the moment, because policies do not build itself. Parameters do not exist before
a network is built. Once issue #1445 is resolved, we should fix `policy.clone()` so that it also copies
parameters.

title: Fix old and new distribution synchronization in on-policy algorithms
body:
In on-policy algorithms, a policy object is cloned to represent the old distribution, to be used
when calculating KL divergence between old and new policies in each optimization epoch.
The cloned policy should have the same parameters in the first place, otherwise it will result in
longer training time and large optimization error in the first epoch. This PR fixes this issue.

This also fixes RL2 to update old policy parameters at the end of each optimization epoch.

title: VecEnvExecutor incorrectly copies dones array
body: `dones` should be a `copy.deepcopy` rather than a reference to `completes`, though changing this to a deepcopy breaks `OnPolicyVectorizedSampler` when used on nonterminating environments.

title: test_mtsac_inverted_double_pendulum is flaky

title: Sampler's don't pickle (correctly)
body:
Currently, samplers generally don't implement the pickle interface. Furthermore, the one sampler that does (`LocalSampler`) assumes that there's no state contained in its workers that wasn't present when the sampler was constructed. This breaks in the following circumstances:
 - The environment was updated after the experiment was started, and the same environment update isn't replicated on resume.
 - The agent / policy has additional state besides its parameters. For example, exploration policies may have internal state that persists across epochs.

Historically, we assumed that such state wasn't possible, and that the runner would reconstruct the sampler in an idempotent way. However, adding pickling support to the existing samplers would not be particularly onerous, so we should just do that, since it would ensure resume works correctly.

title: RaySampler does not use all workers
body:
In release 2019.10, [RaySampler](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/release-2019.10/src/garage/sampler/ray_sampler.py) sees only one of the workers as idle for all iterations after the first iteration. This can be seen with [examples/tf/trpo_swimmer_ray_sampler.py](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/release-2019.10/examples/tf/trpo_swimmer_ray_sampler.py). 

To me it looks like `self._idle_worker_ids` is not correctly updated at the end of `obtain_samples()` [here](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/d6c993526c23c289ebc94635a78186d9bf197f32/src/garage/sampler/ray_sampler.py#L130). Only those workers which have returned with a result are put back in the idle pool. This is a problem because results from some workers are not processed at the end and these workers don't go back into the idle pool. 

A quick fix (?) is to reset the list of idle workers ids to all workers ids at the start of `obtain samples()`. This does result in all the workers being used for all iterations. Since the agent parameters are updated in the next iteration, the samples from the previously not ready workers must be valid. However, I am not totally sure. 

@avnishn @ryanjulian Appreciate it if the fix can be back-ported to 2019.10!

title: deterministic.set_seed does not guarantee full determinism in TensorFlow
body:
Determinism in TensorFlow depends on two seeds: Graph seed and op seed. Currently `deterministic.set_seed()` only set the graph seed, which makes the random sequences generated by all ops be repeatable across sessions, but not when sequences of ops changed.

Setting both graph_seed and op_seed will guarantee full determinism, i.e. calling 
[https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/compat/v1/set_random_seed](set_random_seed) and applying a seed when calling any tf.ops (e.g. `tf.random.uniform([1], seed=1`).

title: Nightly builds are crashing with a segfault
Off-policy algorithms cannot optimize after every time step
body:
Our implementations of off-policy algorithms require using the `OffPolicyVectorizedSampler`. However, that sampler only collects complete paths. Setting `batch_size` to 1 only results in the environment being reset, then a single sample from the start of the rollout being gathered.

This is a major problem, since the algorithms are usually used in a configuration where they train after every sample.

title: PyTorch policies do not accept numpy arrays to get_action()
body: This makes it impossible to use them with e.g. `rollout`. This should be fairly easy to solve by converting the inputs to PyTorch Tensors.

milestone.description: Issues which should be addressed immediately after the v2019.10 release

body: `HerReplayBuffer` is not pickable because it saves a local (nested) function. This breaks any algorithm that has `HerReplayBuffer` as its replay buffer, e.g. `examples/her_ddpg_fetchreach.py`

title: Inconsistent flattening for dict observation between on- and off-policy samplers
body:
`OffPolicyVectorizedSampler` flattens a dict observation while other samplers do not. This breaks `ContinuousMLPPolicyWithModel` who assumes observation is provided as it is, at this line https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/7bb784efdefc7fd8f160718c1d989144ba91e07f/src/garage/tf/policies/continuous_mlp_policy_with_model.py#L150

This issue can be reproduce by running `examples/her_ddpg_fetchreach.py`.

There are also inconsistences in polices' assumption on observation shape. For example, contradicting to `ContinuousMLPPolicyWithModel`, `CategoricalConvPolicyWithModel` assumes observation to be a ndarray. 
https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/7bb784efdefc7fd8f160718c1d989144ba91e07f/src/garage/tf/policies/categorical_conv_policy_with_model.py#L146-L147

title: Make snapshot_config a required argument
body:
Currently, if we don't pass a `snapshot_config` to the runner like this (sorry, I am an old school garage user so I did not catch up with the snapshotter):
```
def run_task(*_):
    with LocalTFRunner() as runner:
```
the snapshots and log data could locate at different locations SILENTLY when we specify a log directory or log prefix.

I suggest that we should make this argument (i.e. the `snapshot_config` of a local runner) required so doing this will at least raise an error. Or, alternatively, I think we should handle this by forcing the snapshotter to use the log directory of dowel and remove the `snapshot_dir` from snapshotter. What do you think?

@krzentner @naeioi @ryanjulian @zequnyu

title: Add agent_info to PyTorch policies
body: Currently, some policies are following the tf tree and `get_actions` returns actions and agent_infos while some of them don't. I think we should just unify this and just follow the tf tree. Can one of you take over this? @lywong92 @yonghyuc

)

title: Fix GaussianMLPRegressor
body:
The `fit` method of GaussianMLPRegressor is creating new `tf.assign` operations every iteration. This will slow down the training. 

This is only a quick fix for `GaussianMLPRegressor` with tests for this bug so that embed2learn can use the new regressor/baseline. I will open an issue for other regressors. This bug also appears at new regressors that are implemented with `model`.

title: No advantage normalization for recurrent policy
body:
In [garage/tf/algos/npo.py](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/master/garage/tf/algos/npo.py), it normalizes the advantages if `self.center_adv` is `True`, but only for non-recurrent policies.
Is this intentional?

title: LocalRunner closes tf sessions it does not own
body:
`garage.experiment.local_tf_runner.LocalRunner` will close its tf session in `__exit__`. However, the session may not have been created by LocalRunner and may be managed by some other entity. Closing externally-owned sessions can lead to unexpected behavior or failures.

Example:
```
with tf.Session() as sess:
  with LocalRunner(sess=sess) as runner:
    # Run an experiment
```
Code will fail with error:
`AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__exit__'`

title: Use tf.variable_scope instead of tf.VariableScope for policies using models
body: Using `tf.VariableScope` will not add a new scope to the graph. This introduces bugs to `model.parameters`.

title: Model class unit test flaw
body:
The tests for pickling models, e.g. GaussianMLPModel, do not test the weights pickling correctly. If `pickle.dumps` is called in another session, rather than the session the model is built, it will not be able to get the weights.

TODO: Fix the test and state clearly in the documentation.

title: Remove config_personal_template.py from setups
body:
The file config_personal_template.py does not longer exist in the garage
repository because the personal configuration is now set using
environment variables.
Since the file cannot be copied anymore, it has to be removed from the
setup scripts to avoid installation errors.

title: commit #585 breaks setup scripts
body:
5 days ago, commit e5dca58a7e3d9054a6afaa0c596774bbf24458af deleted `garage/config_personal_template.py`. However, the setup scripts `setup_linux.sh` and `setup_macos.sh` still reference it in the line
````cp garage/config_personal_template.py garage/config_personal.py````
which causes setup to error out.

from recent tests runs

UserWarning: WARN: <class 'garage.envs.wrappers.fire_reset.FireReset'> doesn't implement 'step' method, which is required for wrappers derived directly from Wrapper. Deprecated default implementation is used.
```

title: Use the right env variable for .bash_rc
body:
The variable BASH_PROF is not defined by setup_linux.sh, causing
problems when attempting to append a string to the file path that should
be in BASH_PROF, which expands to nothing.
The right variable to use is BASH_RC.

title: GaussianMLPRegressor is not unpickled appropriately
body:
Sorry I can't come up with a good title for this but I will describe the problem in details here.

GaussianMLPRegressor has variables (e.g. [`y_mean`](https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/f33a03ea4d71525eabadbe22f31ad0a91607b134/garage/tf/regressors/gaussian_mlp_regressor.py#L156)) that are created for normalizing the inputs and they are not saved during pickling. This will force user to run a variable initialization when they want to use an unpickled GaussianMLPBaseline. However, running initialization will re-initialize the model variables.

This will affect people who want to use a pickled baseline object to resume training or use them to do further learning.

title: Fix caching and CodeCov in garage-ci
body:
The docker image for garage-ci was having the following issues:
- The codecov environment variables were not expanding correctly when
calling docker-run though a makefile in Travis.
- Caching was not working

First, the ci image got its own compose file docker-compose-ci to simply
things. To solve the codecov issue, the (bash<curl) operation was moved
from the makefile to the travis file, since the operation was not 
expanding properly when called from the makefile.
To pass the environment variables of codecov generated in travis, the 
variable ADD_ARGS was added in the makefile to pass these or any other
environment variables required in the future. This was documented in the 
README.md.
For caching, the wrong tag was used, since ":latest" was getting
appended to the name tag, giving an invalid value for cache image name.
Since each image type has its own compose file now, the tags for caching
are now hard-coded to their corresponding image types.
Also, only the presence of the mjkey.txt is needed to install mujoco-py, so an
empty file named mjkey.txt is created in the Dockerfile instead of passing the
real key.
Finally, the file Dockerfile was renamed to Dockerfile.base.

title: Pylint complaints of bad import
body:
Pylint wrongly complaints of bad imports as seen in https://travis-ci.com/rlworkgroup/garage/builds/97882648.

**tl;dr** Pylint get confused by the coexistence of `baselines` in deps and `garage.tf.baselines` in garage. Add an empty `__init__.py` under `garage/tf` to circumvents the problem _(As a workaround)_.

I might later add details on how pylints goes wrong under the hood.

title: Fix setup_xxx.sh scripts

milestone.title: 2018.10 Release
milestone.description: Let's push hard to get a stable release for the fall semester. We'll make large changes to garage once we have a stable base.

body:
### There are some major errors that need to be fixed in order for the scripts to work correctly.
- `Directory ‘.’ is not installable. File ‘setup.py’ not found.`
This script assumes that the individual will run the script in the `garage/` home directory. This should not be assumed.
 >**Potential solution**: recursively determine where the garage directory is located (relative or absolute path), then use that path to locate `setup.py` and replace `.` in the script.


- `SpecNotFound: Runtime error: Can't process without a name.`
This is a conda error, specifically on line 216 in `setup_osx.sh`: `conda env create -f environment.yml`. For some users, running this line with the relative path `environment.yml` will not work.
>**Potential solution**: recursively determine where the garage directory is located (relative or absolute path), then use that path to locate environment.yml and pass the full path in the script.
E.g. `conda env create -f /path/to/environment.yml`.


- Miniconda is not adding a name (i.e. "garage") to the created environment.
```$ conda env list 
# conda environments:
#
                  *  /miniconda/path/to/environment
^ missing garage here
```
>**Potential solution**: Not sure, don't have experience with miniconda. Maybe miniconda doesn't have naming functionality? Though I highly doubt it.

from garage.baselines import LinearFeatureBaseline
from garage.envs.dm_control import DmControlEnv
from garage.misc.instrument import run_experiment
from garage.tf.algos import TRPO
from garage.tf.envs import TfEnv
from garage.tf.policies import GaussianMLPPolicy


def run_task(*_):
    env = TfEnv(DmControlEnv(domain_name='cartpole', task_name='balance'))

    policy = GaussianMLPPolicy(
        env_spec=env.spec,
        hidden_sizes=(32, 32),

    baseline = LinearFeatureBaseline(env_spec=env.spec)

    algo = TRPO(

        n_itr=400,
        discount=0.99,
        step_size=0.01,

    n_parallel=1,
    snapshot_mode="last",
    plot=True,
)

body: I can choose any value (or GaussianMLPPolicy params) I want, and it doesn't change the policy standard deviation. e.g. -1.0 won't cause the policy stddev to fall, and 1.0 won't cause it to rise. This may be because a gradient path is broken between the reward function and the policy std network.

title: Always copy actions if they are modified by the environment

milestone.title: 2018.10 Release
milestone.description: Let's push hard to get a stable release for the fall semester. We'll make large changes to garage once we have a stable base.

body:
When using VectorizedSampler, the actions ndarrary (or a slice thereof) of passed directly to the environment. If the environment modifies the action (e.g. by re-scaling or clipping it), it will modify the action vector used by the optimizer. This is *not* the correct behavior--the actions used by the optimizer should be the ones produced by the policy, regardless of how the environment mangles the actions.

To close this issue, we need to audit each environment (including wrappers) and make sure that any environment which modifies actions in `step()` copies them first.

title: TensorFlow GPU overriden by installation of baselines

milestone.title: 2018.10 Release
milestone.description: Let's push hard to get a stable release for the fall semester. We'll make large changes to garage once we have a stable base.

body:
While installing garage, the package baselines and its dependencies are installed. Among these dependencies, there's the regular version of TF, and even though TF GPU is installed after (if the user picks that option), when both distributions are installed, the regular version of TF overrides the GPU version.
This is an issue inherited from baselines, as seen [here](https://github.com/openai/baselines/issues/146).
A possible solution would be to remove tensorflow before installing tensorflow-gpu, although this may be temporal if baselines is fixed.

title: Pickling is broken in tf/regressors

milestone.title: 2018.10 Release
milestone.description: Let's push hard to get a stable release for the fall semester. We'll make large changes to garage once we have a stable base.

body:
```python
def play(pkl_file):
    with tf.Session() as sess:
        sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())

        # Unpack the snapshot
        snapshot = joblib.load(pkl_file)
        env = snapshot["env"]
        policy = snapshot["policy"]
```

Output:
```sh
tensorflow.python.framework.errors_impl.FailedPreconditionError: Attempting to use uninitialized value
vf/mean_network/hidden_0/W
         [[Node: _retval_vf/mean_network/hidden_0/W_0_0 = _Retval[T=DT_FLOAT, index=0, _device="/job:lo
calhost/replica:0/task:0/device:CPU:0"](vf/mean_network/hidden_0/W)]]
```

Some notes:
* GaussianMLPRegressor defines get/set params:
    ```python
        def get_param_values(self, **tags):
            return LayersPowered.get_param_values(self, **tags)
    
        def set_param_values(self, flattened_params, **tags):
            LayersPowered.set_param_values(self, flattened_params, **tags)
    ```
    This is not necessary if the regressors inherit from Parameterized and call the Parameterized 
    constructor (see `garage/tf/policies/base.py`).
* However, using Parameterized alone does not seem to correct the problem

title: Cleanly terminate all worker processes on an interrupt
body:
When calling function run_experiment and the parameter n_parallel is
bigger than zero, worker processes are created to do parallel sampling
during the training. However, when there's a keyboard interrupt, there
are certain occasions when processes are not completely killed after the
execution has finished.
By checking the PID of these processes using the command "ps -fu | grep
run_experiment", we noticed they had the status code "Sl", where S means
interruptible sleep, so the processes are waiting for a signal to wake
up and continue their execution.
When executing the command "kill -SIGINT <pid>" with the PID of the
sleeping process, we got the python trace back and found that the
processes were sleeping trying to acquire the lock of the inqueue inside
the pool of python multiprocessing.
By default, when a keyboard interruption occurs all processes get
notified, but the notifications are not sent in any order. This could
produce an issue when a process is interrupted and finished without
releasing the lock that other process are waiting for as it's in this
case.
To avoid this problem, the worker processes are forked with SIGINT
blocked, so only their parent will be notified, taking care of
terminating the pool of workers once the keyboard interrupt is caught.

title: spec() wrapper should return garage.spaces types, not gym.spaces types
body: https://github.com/rlworkgroup/garage/blob/master/garage/envs/util.py#L113

title: Remove enclosing_scope and use tf.name_scope()
body: The feature we attempted to implement with enclosing_scope() is properly implemented with the utility tf.name_scope(). Furthermore, enclosing_scope() is implemented with tf.variable_scope(), which can actually create unexpected side effects when defining neural networks (i.e. it makes every primitive and function call have its own set of variables, but in reality we often want shared variables).

title: run_experiment should not leave zombie processes
body:
I have to run this snippet after every run_experiment to clean up:
```sh
ps -fu | grep run_experiment | awk '{print $2}' | xargs kill -SIGINT
```
run_experiment should not leave zombie processes if it's killed with Ctrl-C (SIGINT). This might be fixed by changing joblib to use forkserver mode (#106)

title: box2d_env.py with plot=True raises NotImplementedError

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
Currently when running `examples/trpo_cartpole.py` with `plot=True`, the `render()` function in `box2d_env.py` raises a NotImplementedError on line 358. 

However, commenting out both lines 357 and 358 will fix this issue and correctly draw the plot. This issue is being opened because the potential ramifications for commenting out these lines is unclear.

One potential reason for this new bug could be due to upgrading gym to v0.10, but unclear.

title: TF policies are broken
body:
Some of the policies in tf tree are broken due to #58. Many spaces are converted to gym.spaces but the policies are still checking if the action_space is rllab.tf.spaces.

E.g. `rllab.tf.gaussian_mlp_policy.GaussianMLPPolicy`

title: Fix mujoco env

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
I found an issue in mujoco_env. The MjSim of mujoco_py does not has an attribute of geom_margin, which is used by _get_full_obs(). This is caused by a pr that refactors rllab.mujoco_py to mujoco_py

There might be other issues imported this pr. So a regression test of mujoco envs is desired for this issue.

title: Gym environments should not show a plot when plot=False
body: Imported from https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/31

title: setup_linux.sh fails while installing dm_control
body:
It's missing an absl dependency.

Imported from https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/89

title: setup_linux.sh fails while looking for mujoco 1.5.0 on a clean system
body:
This is probably related to https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/89, since dm_control uses mujoco 1.5.0. We may need to combine setup_mujoco.sh and setup_<platform>.sh

Imported from https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/90

title: Normalization for gym envs
body:
Now that we are using OpenAI gym directly in our RL algorithms, we still need to normalize the environment (actions, observations, rewards) as in https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/blob/integration/rllab/envs/normalized_env.py.

So implement `NormalizedEnv` for `gym.Env`.

Imported from https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/64

title: Asynchronous TensorFlow plotting doesn't work on Mac OSX
body:
Asynchronous plotting for TensorFlow works perfectly fine on Linux using `threading.Thread`, but Mac OS X will not display a window, even if `threading.Thread` is switched to `multiprocessing.Process`, which is how it was implemented using Theano.

Imported from https://github.com/ryanjulian/rllab/issues/127
